ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how to write different types of papers and how to improve my writing skills.
I learned so much about my writing, bad art, and most important to me, learning to abandon preconceptions and how to absorb and evaluate sources of art for yourself.

I learned how to think analytically and write in a more organized format. I feel that my writing improved greatly throughout this course. I was able to get away from the five paragraph format that is taught in high school, and I was able to add more style to my writing.
How to understand bad art.
Comprehensively develop my skills in writing argumentative papers, as well as putting texting conversation with one another, all through the interesting lens of art across media

Class activities such as The Museum of Bad Art helped me with my analysis skills. I have been evaluating various sorts of sources, interpreting them and constructing genuine arguments using these sources - all of which has helped me become more analytical if not abstract, and I believe that it is a person's analytical skills which allow one to think along the abstract spectrum. 

When I entered this class, I was writing chunky paragraphs on the class google doc. But activities such as the formation of quotation sandwiches have helped me a lot with sentence structure, especially making my arguments more concise, to the point and less wordy. 

This class has helped me in identifying the difference between opinions, value judgments, facts, statements and claims so I never have to use assumptious words or phrases again. 

I feel this class has equipped me with a great set of tools for the future, looking forward to writing commercially and publicly if the opportunity arises.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how even though the general course is ENGL 114, there are sections tailored to different interests. Taking an English class sounded terrible to me, but having been able to choose a topic that I genuinely enjoy made the class very interesting.

I have always heard great things about ENGL 114, and this class did not disappoint. Specifically, I think the theme of this class, in general, is a strength because it brought me into an English class. I would consider myself not traditionally interested in English, but was fascinated by the course title and absolutely loved everything about it!
Very interesting and good tea hung.
I love the way the discussions were facilitated in this class, felt constantly productive and engaging

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that this class did everything it could during a pandemic.
I really liked our large-scale class discussions but think the class could possibly be improved by smaller breakout discussions as well!
The live in person seminar was great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! It is a great introduction to college writing.
YES! I loved it so much. I would recommend it for both English and non-English majors.

Yes! The subject is very interesting. We were able to compare works of "bad art" and look for redeeming qualities. We also discussed the nature of Hallmark movies and how they are both repulsive and intriguing. We similarly talked about reality television shows and songs that are popular but pointless. I was never bored in this class and I learned a lot.
Yes, it is a great course to improve your writing.
Absolutely. If you have either a passive or active interest in art of any kind this is a really interesting way to engage with it

Yes. This writing course is not at all hefty like the other writing courses I've heard about. It has a small workload and actually explores all formats of art. Technically you can write and discuss whatever you want to as long as its related to bad art (your views are really heard in this class).

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Peer workshops in small groups
Breakout rooms.
N/A
